Ray Sanford has been getting electroconvulsive treatment, also known as electroshock and ECT, since the end of May.
For Ray, the process works like this: Every week or two, he's taken to a hospital where a medical technician attaches electrodes to his head and delivers electrical current into his brain.
The current causes a seizure.
For reasons that doctors still don't understand, some patients with severe depression or mania get better after having ECT.
But the potential benefits don't matter to Ray.
He says he dreads the shocks and wants them to stop.
It's scary as hell.
Ray is 54 years old.
He has a receding hairline and a salt-and-pepper beard.
He walks with a cane and his hands shake slightly, a side effect, he says, from some of the medication he's talking.
We've met up in the basement of the small group home where he lives so we can talk without disturbing his roommates.
I'm warned by his legal guardians, who are present for the interview, that Ray gets tired easily, so this conversation may not last long.
I ask him what bothers him about getting ECT.
Besides being scary, he says the electroshock makes his head hurt for at least a day, and it's wrecking his memory.
One of the things that I have a problem with is certain people, I can't remember their names anymore.
I should be able to remember their names, since I've known some of them a long time.
And I can't quite remember their names.
And don't ask me to tell you their names because I won't remember.
Ray's doctors aren't allowed to discuss his case with NPR.

His guardian, Lutheran Social Services, says the courts have determined that Ray isn't incompetent to make decisions regarding his own welfare, so he can't give his doctors permission to discuss his private medical record.

They wanted to pull Ray out of a particularly lengthy psychotic episode that began a year ago.

Ray didn't want to talk about his hospitalization with NPR.

Sitting on a cream-colored chair in her tiny retirement-community apartment, Marilyn Sanford clutched a picture frame showing Ray in happier times.
I put in their baby picture and then their high-school graduation picture.
He didn't graduate, but I've always liked that picture of him.
He was a much beloved child.
Marilyn says her son had a very happy childhood, but by the time he turned 17, he began acting out in disturbing ways.

She says episodes like these reoccurred like clockwork every 18 months to two years throughout her son's adult life.

When Marilyn heard this past summer that a court had ordered involuntary ECT for her son, she thought it seemed like a reasonable option.
